I love coming here. Amazing sushi. But best of all its fried rice is like no other. I'm not a big sushi fan I don't order anything but crab, shrimp and salmon but I must say its very good here.

I loved it. Sat down at the sushi bar and right away got greeted and asked what i like to drink. Very attentive and quick with the food. Food was delicious, fresh and just yummy. I will most definitely be going back if I'm ever in Vegas again. Oooh and asked for a roll that wasn't on the menu and with no hesitation he agreed to make it for me which I loved. Thank u!!! Ooh and lunch prices were just right.

I think this place is great!! It's in a good location but since it's not on the strip the prices are average. Very awesome chicken katsu. Also sampled a few other items they had (forgot the names, but they were all good.) The food itself would only get a 3 star rating but the fact they have four different seating options is not only unique but sure to please almost anybody. Plus, our server was very friendly. If you're craving sushi this is the place for you.
Great place to dine with family and friends at both of Osaka's teppanyaki and seated areas.  Prices are reasonable and they have friendly service.

I've been here many times during the years and it's an okay place. Everything they serve is simply average nothing really that stands out, but it's still decent.

Most of the time the service is friendly and delivery of food is accurate and quickly delivered. I like this location, because it's closer to the center of town, so if I'm running out of time I can come here for a quick bite. This isn't the best sushi place in town, but it's good enough to recommend.

This is one of my favorite restaurants in Vegas and it has been that way going on 10 years.  Its got a real neighborhood feel too it.  Food is always fresh and service is super polite and prompt.  I just love to go there after work and take off my shoes and lounge around on the pillows.  I recommend the chicken teriyaki, tempura shrimp and veggies and Japanese sandwiches.

Got food poisoning here yesterday. What a terrible post meal experience.. can't ever come here again. At the time, the food was an overall good meal, however I started the worst food sickness about 3-5 hours later. This, I will never forget. Culprit is the ginger, rice or filet tataki (not sure on sp).

This is the place that made me a believer!  I have always been leary of sushi, but after my experience here I love it now.  Not been to a ton of places, but this is the place I base all others on.  And none have come close.  I can't get enough of the 911 roll.  And everyone I have told about this place all agree this place is tops.  Also you can't beat there sushi happy hour and the ambiance all in all Osaka is great.

Went to Osaka again today. This place has been in Las Vegas longer than I have, like 48+ years !! Their food is consistently fresh, the fish tastes like fresh caught, just like it should ! Great Service and quality food make Osaka on West Sahara a true Las Vegas treasure !

Great service, all the rolls I tried were amazing. Some of the best sushi I've ever had. Good sake selection. Would come back. 

However, sitting at the sushi bar sucks: the countertop is so shallow that your knees clash with the wall beneath the counter. Could not find a comfortable seating position.

This restaurant is wonderful! It is lovely inside. The decor is beautiful and clean. The staff is very friendly and the sushi is fresh and very well prepared! 

They also have bento boxes for those who aren't into sushi, which are among the best I've seen. They aren't stingy with the plates and everything is fresh and flavorful! I have been back several times over the past few weeks and they are consistent. 

I would recommend this restaurant to anyone without worrying about it missing the mark. Bravo!

Love this place! 
Like what everyone is saying about the layout is kinda weird but still great ambiance, once you get to the Japanese seating area. And the place has plenty of seating even great for parties or dinner events. 
Plus if you go on Groupon you get some kind of discount but I think its only for the anthem location.  
Customer service is pretty good. They even gave us a little history about Osaka. How the owner was a great guy. He wanted to help people with no work so he opened a restaurant. There is a painting of him in the sushi bar. Also found out that they are NOT associated with the Lake Mead location. 

The food is amazing! I mean your never gonna get it as fresh as Japan but taste is on point. Kinda brings me back to Japan. 
It is a little pricey but totally worth it specially  on happy hour! I love love the tempura bam. 
The curry is pretty good as well and is a big portion. And of course the sushi!
I definitely recommend this place. It doesn't look much considering the location. But its a  MUST TRY!
Delicious, fresh seafood!  Outstanding service!  We came in on a Tuesday afternoon and did not have to wait to be seated to have sushi only.

This restaurant  is so weird. I made a reservation but  they said they dont take reservation from 4-8pm ...just after 8pm  for night . We are fine with that . that is why we take 8pm with show cooking on table...but when we come on time, they don't put us on  that table instead other one. They said we need to wait for 30mis. We are ok...but after that they said we need to wait more time... so bad. We take reservation already. Why we need to wait many time. We spend 30mins for driving to this restaurant...but it is tooooooo....o bad. 
I don't eat food yet so i give this restaurant 2 stars for bad treatment.
Great 911 roll if you like spicy. The oh my god roll is very tasty too. THe interior is very Japanese like, low floor tables and bamboo, nice atmosphere, friendly service

Osaka is hands down the best Japanese restaurant in the Las Vegas area. I always try to leave The Strip to get a more mellow, authentic experience and this place is my first pick. Fresh sushi, a large menu, great service, fair pricing and tasty specials all make this place the go-to when in Vegas.

It's a must to stop into Osaka anytime I'm in Vegas! 

Service is great, food's yummy and there's many options, and I love the vibe in the restaurant! I can lounge and sip on sake or do sake bombs with help from the chefs!

Came here to try this place on a Wednesday night. We wanted to sit in those booths that you take your shoes off Japanese style. I love this concept. Only thing I would have to say is that the pillows to sit on in this room is kinda old. Some looked new but some were old or dirty. Our servers did an excellent job bringing out everything fast and tending to us. My boyfriend and I ordered the Ron Special Boat. It was filling and good. Didn't care for the potato salad that came with the boat. Everything else was good. The sauce for the tempura was my boyfriends favorite sauce. Before we got our boat we got a refreshing cucumber salad and the miso soup with noodles in it. I love that their soup has noodles in it! It was delicious. The cucumber salad was really good and part of my favorite as well! I also ordered some hot sake. It was smooth and the server did a great job recommending the sake choice for me. 
Our Ron special boat had beef, chicken yakitori, came with rice, potato salad, sashimi (salmon, tuna, and I believe yellowtail), California roll, and tempura. It filled the two of us up and we had to get the rest to bring home. Their desserts looked good as well. I think this is a good spot for hibachi and Japanese dining. I think if they updated the pillows then the place would have a better new look and feel to it.
Amazing food! Can't stop talking about it!! Will definitely go back next time we're in Las Vegas.
Overpriced restaurant and plenty of MSG in their food. Looking for a heart attack or a stroke? This is the place. Service is up & down.

I have been craving deep fried ice cream not the corn flakes kind but the like batter kind. I saw a picture of Osaka's tempura fried ice cream and it www just what I was looking for.  It's amazing and you get a very large portion lol I wouldn't mind sharing...I'll definitely be a frequent flyer

When you look at the outside of Osaka, don't be fooled by how it looks.  The parking is small and narrow and there are no windows outside.  However, once inside, you'll notice the ambience is nice and you will dine Japanese style.  Yes, taking off your shoes or flip-flops and sitting on the floor.  I must say that this is one of the best sushi places I have ever been to. 

The sushi is good and the presentation is simple.  The udon is good as well, but I was unable to finish it.  I ordered the Oh My God sushi and I noticed that they added lettuce to their sushi.  I found it strange, but I found not difference in taste.  The sushi wasn't mind blowing and I don't know why they named it Oh My God.  

Service was great.  Our (I went with my sister and boyfriend) server was always checking on us if we wanted more water or anything else to eat.  We only had to ask him once for refill.  He was always on top of things. 
 
Overall, I wouldn't mind coming here again.  Maybe I should order the San Diego Salmon.

One of my favorite places to eat at, especially for sushi! Their service is awesome and I love their tempura, miso soup, teriyaki chicken, japanese lasagna roll, etc. They also have great desserts! My favorite is the tiramisu. I know, you're thinking.. at a Japanese restaurant? Well, it's some of the best I've had & I've eaten tiramisu in Little Italy in NYC. Go check it out!

Osaka Bistro is awesome, if you appreciate quality sushi that is. The sushi/sashimi is fresh and authentic. I got the medium sashimi platter which was enough for four to share. It had a good assortment of fish from snow crab and fresh abalone to hamachi and hirame. I'm drooling just thinking back to that sashimi platter! I also had another platter with the various types of nigiri sushi that I ordered. The amaebi and kinmedai were terrific! The toro melted in my mouth! I also had the shigoku oysters which were fantastic and fresh! There are many other sushi rolls to choose from and a large menu with items from the kitchen if sushi is not your preference. My mom loves their sukiyaki. She and my dad have been coming here for years and now that I've seen why, I'll be back for sure!

I've been a fan of Osaka for awhile. They've been around for awhile. They're a steady sushi spot. They've thrown in some new items as they've aged. The "bistro" part was only recently added, at least to my recollection they were once only known as Osaka. The restaurant, although in a seedy part of town, has been kept up well. I'm sure at some point in time, this spot was a GOOD spot in town. But you can't really help what happens to an aging city. You can help keeping your restaurant clean and nice looking, which Osaka has done.

I enjoy the atmosphere of Osaka, it is dimly lit when you first walk in and around the tepanyaki areas. However, the dining area is well lit with nice, clean, wooden tables. The service has always been up to par when I have visited. The servers are well versed on the menu, they are around consistently to refill drinks (I usually always order a hot green tea). 

On my last visit I went with a friend because I had a LivingSocial deal, which they honored without any hesitation. I had a few different items: Age Dashi Tofu. I thought it was pretty good, although I have had a better age dashi tofu at Cafe de Japon. The serving they give at Osaka is quite large. I shared some with my friend. The broth it was in was a teeny bit salty for me, but I did drink it all up. Moving on to sushi, because that's what I came for. I ordered the Lisa Lisa roll (shrimp tempura, cream cheese, avocado, eel sauce). It was decent. Not the best or worst roll I've ever had. The tempura was on the soggy side. Wish it had had a more crispness to it. Next: temaki (hand roll). I always get a hand roll when I eat sushi. I ordered the Miki's special, it's simple: crab, massago, and mayo. It was good. And lastly: nigiri. I ordered the sweet shrimp (Ama Ebi). This was my favorite by far. I wish I had just ordered a bunch of these. They were stuffed full, very generous portions. 

My friend also allowed me to try some of the food she got. I unfortunately cannot remember what it was she ordered. But one thing was the Japanese pancake, which I really liked because it had seafood in it. 

We ended our meal with the Bomba - chocolate peanut butter! I highly recommend this. It was very good. 

Overall I like Osaka. I will be back again. They have a very extensive menu and I would like to try more sushi as well as their Udon.

Always love coming here for real, traditional Japanese food. Osaka keeps an authentic menu, prepared to perfection, which is getting harder to find with all of these fusion-type Asian restaurants sprouting up. While that's alright sometimes, when I want an authentic Japanese dish made right, I come here. Love the ambiance & the staff is very friendly also.

Food and service was amazing. I was unclear from the entry on where to sit or if anything else was available for seats other than the few tables. However the establishment clearly needs a remodel but the food made me forget about my environment. I will return!

I love the little hole in the wall joints and found this place on Yelp.  We walked in and immediately sat at the bar, which we love to do.

We didn't realize that they had an entire back section where it was more or less traditional Japanese seating which is lower to the ground.  

Great food.  Loved the Sushi and the service was great.

This is a layback take off your shoes(literally) Tatami tables kind of place, cozy and comfortable place to enjoy delicious Japanese cuisine. Love the variety of prices not so expensive(lots of options) can be if you don't take the time to read the menu....
Overall it's a great place for Sushi, teriyaki platter, or Kobe-beef.
Delicious japanese food. Order the two boats the Titanic and the Ron. U can't go wRONg. Thank me later

I do not like this place, it feels like I was pushed through like cattle. The food is not that great and they never come to your table even to offer you more napkins or forks. I would not go there again

I stopped writing reviews on Yelp because it was too time consuming, but after eating at this restaurant, I can't help but tell the world about our experience, one that I hope will make other people wary of coming here.

We arrived at Osaka on a typical Saturday afternoon (1pm-ish) and was shown a table in the back room (where the tables were larger).  As we walked past the first room upon entering, I noticed that it was fairly empty but it didn't struck me as odd since there are so many restaurants to choose from in Las Vegas.

We sat down and were given multiple menus, each one with something different in it.  I guess this could be a good thing since I like having lots of choices.  We ordered our drinks (hot green tea and iced green tea) and browsed the menus for omakase, which we heard from someone (ahem) that it is worth coming here for.

After everyone in our party arrived (there were 5 of us), we asked the waitress about their omakase and she completely hesitated. I thought that was strange considering this should be a simple question.  She said she'll be right back, so we sat there, thinking maybe she's just new or something.  But even so... o_O.

She came back and in broken English asked us if we wanted sashimi or sushi, and we said a little of both.  She then proceeded to say that it's $100 for all four people that wanted it, and I confirmed if it was $100 per person, or if it was $100 for all four people because that makes a HUGE difference.  She said $100 for four people, so we agreed.

After ordering the "omakase" - I realized that she must have ordered us the plate of normal sashimi/sushi that was on the menu.  I remember seeing $50 for 2 people for something, so with 4 people, she just doubled it.  I thought sure... why not.  We were going to try their assortment of rolls, but given that the omakase is supposed to be good, I decided to give it a try.

The first plate of sashimi came out looking decent.  I'm not too familiar with the names and the translation for the type of fish, so I'm just going to say that I tried just about everything on the menu and only a couple items tasted okay.  There were quite a few nasty bites in between, including one in which I had to spit out.  Now, I'm not a sushi snob at all, but when I have to do that, it means it's NOT good.  My companions agreed, and another person had to go thru that ritual later on in the meal as well (said one of the fish tasted grainy too).  Fortunately, our napkins were right in front of us.  =)

As an additional note, we received 2 additional plates of sushi rolls which were supposed to be part of the omakase deal.  We thought it was just so-so as well... perhaps even bad.

At the end of the meal, we noticed the $100 + $70 on top of our other charges.  We asked about the $70 and they said it was for the 2 plates of sushi rolls that accompanied our sashimi omakase plate. Needless to say, that $70 was a surprise because we were told  it was $100 for four people.  If they told us they were going to bring additional sushi plates for $35 each, I think we would've either said no, or ordered or own rolls.  Ugh.  I hate when mess-ups like this happen.

We told our waitress about the issue and she left to talk to the owner/mgr.  The owner/mgr. came by quite awhile later to ask us what the issue was.  We explained clearly about the unexpected charge and the miscommunication but he wouldn't budge.  In fact, he brought up how good of a quality the fish were, and given that, this is still a good deal.  The whole time, I kept thinking if I should tell the truth about the quality of his fish, but I kept my mouth shut in case he was going to give us a break.

I suppose we all could've said something because at the end, nothing happened out of the negotiation.  He wouldn't even take the charge of one $35 plate of sushi off, so we paid, left, and vowed never to come back.  

I've had a lot of sushi before, but I would rank this as the worst sushi AND experience ever.  There are a ton of other great sushi restaurants in Vegas, so look it up on Yelp and go there.  You will not regret it.
Soooooooo disgusting didnt like food and it SMELLED like BATHROOM dont recomend this place

Saw Osaka Japanese Bistro highlighted on a recent Triple D episode and had to try it. We were in Vegas for the weekend and sick of casino food so this was the perfect alternative. 

Restaurant atmosphere: 
My mom - born and raised in Osaka, Japan - was skeptical as soon as we pulled into the parking lot. She was even more skeptical as we entered the establishment. We were greeted with a black wall! It's drab, a bit dark and the decor is sadly lacking in so many ways...outdated, dingy and not so appealing. 

We opted to sit in the tatami room vs. at the tables near the sushi bar. The set-up...taking off of the shoes, tatami mats (I suspect those tatami mats haven't been cleaned in a long time!) GROSS. 

If you know anything about the Japanese culture you know that cleanliness is at the top of the list. The second generation owners of this establishment need to take note of this and make an effort to create an atmosphere which is bright, clean and inviting. 

Food: Mom ordered the sashimi and tempura combo $22. She said the sashimi was delicious but she was not happy with the rest of her meal. The sunomono cucumbers were crunchy and they're not supposed to be served that way. The rice - plain ol rice - was not cooked thoroughly. RICE - served any way is KEY in any respectable Japanese restaurant!! The miso soup was ok. I ordered the Nebeyaki Udon. The base was good but overall I wasn't impressed. 

The rolls are way too overpriced and I just wasn't going to pay $15-$20 for a 'specialty' roll! 

Service: our waitress was super nice. I think her name was Haruko. She spoke fluent Japanese which was a plus for my mom. She made suggestions, was attentive and checked in on us several times. There were additional servers that came to check on our dining experience as well and they were very nice as well. 

The restroom: F'in disgusting!!! What the heck! You couldn't even wash your hands as there was only a trickle of water! Is this the ONLY restroom in the establishment???!!! Is this where the servers, cooks and SUSHI CHEF washes their hands after they relieve themselves??!!  The hands they will use to prepare and serve your food???!!!! This is a health code violation! 

I don't think the average diner is aware of an authentic Japanese dining experience. It definitely isn't at Osaka Japanese Bistro. We were disappointed to say the least. 

1 star rating = half for service and half for sashimi!

My cousin loves this place. We were actually seated at Steak N Shake and we had this epiphany that we should go get sushi instead. So we got up and drove all the way up the I-15 to Osaka.

When you enter, you're greeted by a blank wall. What is this - a Japanese Speakeasy? You then turn right and go through another door that takes you to a small sushi bar area. From this initial view, you'd think the place was tiny. If you continue to the back and left, though, you discover that the place can seat quite a lot of people. They have a Teppanyaki area and a surprising number of private booths and traditional looking Japanese sunken dining tables. The space is very aesthetically pleasing.

Unfortunately, when it came to the food, I was disappointed. I really wasn't that hungry, but I tried everything that my cousin ordered. We stuck to their late night special menu that is available 10pm-2am.

* Beef Tataki Salad - It looked amazing, but it lacked flavor. I think I've only ever had Beef Tataki at Ichiza and theirs runs circles around Osaka's.
* King Crab Tempura - This was easily the best thing we ordered. Delicious.
* Salmon Skin (half) Roll - This also lacked flavor. I'm kind of a purist in that I like to eat sushi exactly how the chef made it. I never use soy sauce or add wasabi. I stuck to my guns on this, despite the roll really needing the extra flavor.
* Screaming Orgasm (ahi sashimi on top of some salad) - This also looked amazing. It had better flavor than the Beef Tataki, but I wasn't blown away by it. The dressing was a little too vinegary.

On the plus side, the service was excellent. The two ladies that served us were extremely friendly and attentive to our needs. The green tea tasted great and was the perfect thing on my still recovering throat. Whenever I was running low on tea, the lady would come back and top it off promptly.

I really hate giving less than three stars, but I must stay true to the rating system. Indeed, I have experienced better. It's too bad because the service and decor of Osaka are top notch.

Food was good, but after the meal were told only cards with chips are taken. My bank doesn't have a chip and I was told to go to a cash machine. The managers solution was not acceptable and a self printed sign adjacent to the entry door is not acceptable! David the manager was unprofessional and unable to handle the situation. His response was childish and has made a loyal customer of over six years decide to never return! A negative star is appropriate for the actions of the manager alone!

Who would have thought that the desert could serve some good fish?  Well after much searching through the phone book and online listings, I found a great Japanese restaurant while vacationing in Las Vegas.  Every time I'm the area, I always end up having dinner here at least once.  I'm big on the raw fish, and Osaka takes the cake for having really good sushi while not hammering too hard on the price. And it's not one of those Asian fusion restaurants on the Strip, so that adds to its appeal.  

If you're in the mood for Japanese, try this place.  Plus they have combo dinners and soups that would appeal to the non-raw fish eaters too.
I love this place!  O-Toro all day!  They always have some sort of fish that's not on the typical menu.  The mussels are out of this world.  Go and enjoy good sushi here.

First of all Kenji and Himae are fast and friendly so sit at the bar.  The quality of the fish is amazing. I say don't fill up on rice eat sashimi or nigiri pairs.  The garlic tuna( maguru) is delicious. Also try the Shikoku oysters amazing.  I can't say there was anything I didn't like my friend ate 20 pieces of himachi, so it must have been good. Kenji also made me a lemon salmon roll with avocado and cucumber inside which wasn't on the menu. Great people and high quality food!

Absolutely my favorite sushi place in Vegas! The food is delicious and at a reasonable price but more importantly very clean. Meaning: I have never gotten sick from eating here. This is a common scare with eating any food raw. I trust this place, especially for my "sushi virgin" friends. Favorite rolls: Oh My God, Japanese Lasagna, and a simple salmon nigiri (oh so fresh and sweet!).  If you come with a group of people, they have "sushi boats," which are literally wooden boats full of sushi (prefixed selection though). There is no all you can eat menu but I'm not really into that. Just go to any Osaka location, you will not be disappointed!

Been coming here for the past 10 years and we can't have enough of this place, tried a lot of places in Vegas but this place Rocks!!! The Sushi Chef Jaime knows what we like and we don't , as soon as you walk in the door they will greet you and call you by your name of course if you come here often like we do lol!
Everything is fresh ready to serve as order! Tried pretty much everything off the menu and what can I say? It's really good! Highly recommend this place for Family, friends or even date night!

Osaka's Bistro was okay. I have definitely experienced better. I thought being an older establishment it would be better. Businesses do not stay around 30+ years if they are bad. 

I would say the food was average for Teppanyaki. There was nothing fantastic about it. The facility is incredibly small, OLD, and definietly seen better days. I thought the private rooms were probably the best part, however, I did not dine in one. 

There was only one bathroom, and it was not exactly clean. The bar was small, drinks were overpriced and the sushi was so-so. Overall it was an average experience, with average food, average service and an expensive price tag. we paid $160.00 for four people. I will not be going again.

My partner an die always go there to eat sushi and fry rice, but last night we had David has a server and was terrible! I didn't see him before there but he did a really bad job. no water, we order the first plate of sushi and wait more than 20 minutes to get the second order and never show. went to the cashier to paid my bill and he was ether chilllin, and when I told him very generous about the waiting he didn't said nothing and either good night or so, very very unprofessional ....

I love sushi..but I was a bit disappointed  with this company. .. service seems to be slow. .. and when I ordered  yellowtail nigiri I asked for ponzu sauce on it with jalapeo and siracha on top they said they weren't able to do it because they were to busy in the back room....so I told them to give me a side of all three so I can do it myself...it's not an all you can place ...so not sure why they were not able to do it....im spending the money for each piece of sushi..
Amazing as usual. The food is great and the service is exceptional. It's not just good for sushi, the udon here is the best we've had in Vegas.

I am a HUGE fan of Sushi. I have been to this location 3 or 4 times now and I am hooked! I live in Chinatown, this place is so good that I actually leave Chinatown to eat here.

What is so good?
-The Seating! This place is huge. They have sushi bar seating, table seating in the back and Hibachi. 
- The Service! The service is ALWAYS spot on. I have sat in all parts of this location and it is always perfect. The staff speaks clearly so I don't feel like I need to do sign language unlike some sushi places in Vegas...
-The Dessert! I never thought I would find an asian restaurant with amazing dessert, but this place takes the cake... Or should I say chocolate ice cream amazining-ness ;)
I actually LOVE the gelato!

They have a full bar which is always nice as well :)

I'm big on first impressions, so when friends said this place was good, we decided to check it out.

Our waitress was very nice. The sushi was descent and the beer selection was great.

Here's the bad: terribly slow service. It took over 30mins to make a simple roll. Luckily we dined with friends so we weren't in a hurry but we hardly saw our waitress. I shouldn't have to flag people down just to find out the status of an order. When she did finally return, she gave us our check. She never came back. Had to go to the counter to pay which is no big deal but I waited for 20mins just to pay. Staff just walked by me and several people waiting to pay, not even acknowledging anyone.

I won't return. There is a huge selection of sushi places I would rather go to.

Ordered a late night pick-up dinner of 5 assorted rolls and some kimchi.
The sushi was very good, and the prices very reasonable.

A staple of mine while I was going to school down the street, I am almost obligated to write a review for this fine establishment. A sushi joint that has yet to let me down. 

Osaka serves all of their items a la carte, so no AYCE. But if you have the extra money and want better quality sushi than what you would get from a AYCE place, come here.

Anytime of day is a good time to come, they have lunch and late night specials. The rolls and nigiri are always fresh and delicious, and I regularly order their various bento boxes, combo meals, and appetizers. I am more of a nigiri guy, but this place has plenty of appetizing and unique rolls that I will often order. As I stated earlier, this place has yet to let me down, I have ordered a lot of different items off the menu, and they are always on point.

The service is always top notch. The wait staff is always attentive, and will always customize your order to your liking. I've never gotten a wrong order, food that took forever to come out, or items missing. If you decide to eat at the bar, the sushi chefs are awesome, and will always start up conversation to be friendly and to see what you would want to order and make suggestions. One of my go to chefs is Oscar. He is normally there during the lunch hours, and always makes awesome rolls. He even does his own custom order of baked mussels with Sriracha sauce that is awesome, ask for it, and he will be happy to make it for you.

While not necessarily a con, it can be pricey to get your fill here  if you just plan on eating sushi. But it comes with better quality of food, so it almost cancels itself out. They at least have a reward card here to accumulate some free food after a couple of visits.

It is one of the older sushi spots in Vegas for a reason. Top quality food with awesome service is always a good combo when eating out somewhere.

Been waay too long since I've come here. And how I've missed it.  The fish is always super fresh , osaka rice and baked mussels are always a pleasure.  We have the ultimate osaka roll, lisa lisa, unagi roll, yum yum roll, and rainbow roll. A wide variety of goodness.  Don't be afraid to step out of your comfort zone and try something new , they will not disappoint.  As always service was a pleasure,  our waiter was very fast and friendly as well!

The food was excellent. We got food from the grill and it was the best I've had in a long time. The restaurant is small and fills up so I would try to call and make a reservation if you want to get a seat during prime time.

Very American style sushi, not what I was expecting. I like the taste of raw fish and don't appreciate nigiri coming from the chef with so much wasabi the fish can't be tasted, especially if that is the experience on the majority of the pieces. Rolls aren't much better, the Aces and Yum Yum were  bland, and in the case of the Aces over powered by sauces. Total price was $90 for two (Friday 6/20/14). If you like Wasabi more than fish, and prefer McDonald's to In&out this place might be for you,  but if you'd like even a hint of tradition or subtle flavors look elsewhere.

I lived in Las Vegas for a couple of years and this is one of the places I miss the most.  They always have good food and have never disappointed me.

On this visit my hubby had some assorted sushi - which he just loved - and I had a combination dinner.  The tempura was cooked perfectly and the chicken was moist and delicious.

this is my favorite place for sushi that doesn't have an all you can eat deal. it looks small from the outside but once you're in you  have a variety of seats from the sushi bar or tables or private booths. my favorite roll is matsui #55. the sashimi is consistently fresh. service is very friendly. if you can't decide what you want by reading it off the menu they have plasma tvs at every booth that show pictures of each roll with their names. 

this location has pretty much the same menu as the eastern location. the lake mead location is separately owned and operated with a completely different menu. 

they also have a VIP card available that you use each time you eat and it accumulates a 'bonus' which gives you a discount off your next visit after you accumulate $10.
I love Osaka but a few things I didn't like like the fried rice and had king crab sushi once that had ice particles.

Decided to come over here off the strip with some friends.  And since I rarely go off-strip whenever I'm in Vegas, I figured I'd give it a shot and grabbed a taxi.

That said, I was generally impressed by the ratio of price to sushi during lunch time compared to sushi on the strip.  The quality was pretty good overall.  Though, I honestly forgot what I ordered though since I had more sake than sushi (something along the lines of a badass samurai or something), but I had no issues with the sushi.

Let me start out by saying that Osaka has some damn good sushi and reasonable prices. The booths in the back are cool and they have a very large menu selection.

Now let me get to the part where I will never forgive them for doing what they did:

I had made a reservation for 16 people 2 weeks in advance of my birthday for dinner. I checked back with them several times during those 2 weeks, including 24 hours before and they kept telling me it was all good and they would have my table ready at the exact time.

Well, I showed up on my birthday and was told they didn't have my reservation. ANYWHERE. And that I will have to wait until a table is finally available.

My friends and I waited for over an hour, when they finally came to check on us because we were starting to fill up the seats in their cramped bar area, they offered us a couple free drinks after which they told me we will still have to wait another hour for a table.

Are you kidding me? On my birthday? Screw you, Osaka. Your organizational skills are horrible and your sushi doesn't make up for your lousy service. Even on my previous trips to this restaurant, the service is always either really slow or they mess something up on your bill or they forget to get you an item you ordered, yet I have never complained because I thought I broke even with how good the sushi was.

Well, never again. And I would actually like to thank the horrible staff at Osaka for my introduction to Ichiza, who have WAY better sushi and are so friendly and prompt with their service. 

The gist: Osaka has horrible service, go to Ichiza instead. It's right by there near Chinatown and has much better food, prices and service even though it's about half the size of Osaka.

It's been a long time since I last visited Osaka. Boy, what a difference. It used to be a traditional Japanese restaurant, but now, it's turned into a fusiony bistro. I should've read the reviews on here before going.

The restaurant is now separated into tatami rooms, teppanyaki, sushi bar etc -- we got the tatami room.... which was fine. We got a sushi platter, zaru soba, selections from their robatayaki menu and agedashi tofu. The zaru soba was actually really good. Robatayaki items weren't bad either -- skimpy portions though. The sushi however, blows! I was so damn disappointed in the poor quality we were given. They used to be fantastic.

After this visit, I really won't be returning again. I like my sushi traditional. I'm kinda a stickler about that. The agedashi tofu was quite dismal too, not true authentic agedashi tofu at all. It was so dismal that the young man refused to eat it and he was the one who ordered it.

The service was attentive though hence the extra star. They have a late night menu with discounted prices after 10pm.

I like Osaka mostly because they have good sake samplers and decent food for those who don't eat fish.  I have been here with friends on numerous occasions and have always managed to find something to eat without fish.  Having lived in Japan for years, I like to think my broken nihongo has a hand in me getting what I would like...

Love the Inari and the tofu soup was bland but not too bad.  The tea here is one of the reasons I like to come here..sooo tasty.  

The Sake is great I had rice, cold, warm and flavored and enjoyed almost all of it.  Great to go with a group of friends, sit in the back on the tatami and drink, eat and be merry.  The waiter was kind of nice to give us the some remainders of open bottles since were shutting the place down.  A big bonus because it was normally not something I would order because of the expense.  

The place is good for groups, and the seating is somewhat private so you can have a good time.  Like all tatami you can take your shoes off and sit cross legged which I love.

Great ambience. I love the customer service here i been coming here for a little over a year now. I am NOT very open to many sushi restaurants because i have gotten sick. I have NEVER gotten sick here at osaka and my food from the kitchen is always fresh and Hot. 

I onyl eat a few things in a sushi Restaurant and its usually not on the menu and have to be customized to my liking... they always make my custom sushi roll to my liking with a smile every time s/o to Heimi hes a Kool Guy. I also eat shrimp Ebbi whichi is great here as well. See pics below for what I eat every time. Thanks Osaka

What can I say? The BEST JAPANESE RESTAURANT IN VEGAS! ^_^ 
I love their rolls, their sashimi are so fresh and delicious!  My fav dinner dish is Teriyaki beef, they are smoky!  They have Teppan table but I always prefer the sitting at the tatami room, cause it's so cozy and private if you want to bring your partner.  Service is wonderful, and food came out fast.  For desert, I recommend the green tea mousse, they have the most prefect taste, not too sweet and not too creamy.

It's late on a Sunday night and the BF suggests trying out the original Osaka after having visited their second location a few weeks back. 

Walking through the front door, you immediately face a wall.  Not the most feng shui I'm sure, but make a right down the hall and you'll see another entrance which brings you right to the sushi bar.  I noted to the BF that this location was way smaller, and he then pointed out they had more room in the back.  We took a walk down there after eating to check out their tatami room (lots of space), semi-private booths, and a hibachi grill area too.  They are pretty fancy here with slide shows running on a computer screen at every booth in the back.  I would be even more impressed if it was a touch screen where you can order all your food by pressing your selection.  That would be super high tech!  

Anyway, back to the review and the food.  The menus are pretty much the same at both locations, for the most part.  From their late night happy hour menu, this is what we ordered:

* Shishamo ($2.80) - It came with three pieces.  Again a bit tougher than what I'm used to.  They seasoned it with black pepper, but I asked for some salt to give it a little more kick too.

* Korean-Style Spicy Chicken ($4.50) - It's literally stir-fried chicken with Korean spicy sauce on a bed of lettuce.  I wasn't sure if the lettuce was garnish or to eat.  Oh well, I ate it.

* Crazy Horse Roll ($4.20) - It's tuna, salmon, masago and mixed together with spicy sauce.  It's a very basic roll, but pretty good.

* Fire Roll ($3.90) - Crab meat and spicy sauce.  Unfortunately, it looks like the CA rolls you buy from the supermarket, but without the avocado in it.  It had a bit of kick in it.

And from their regular menu: 

* Ankimo ($6.95) - Monkfish liver...oh how I love this stuff.  It's an acquired taste.  I like to soak my chunk in ponzu sauce and then break off a tiny piece and savor each little morsel.  The BF likes to dunk his piece into the sauce and then toss the whole thing in his mouth.  He likes to then mush it around in his mouth.  Haha!

They are known for their exotic and colorful rolls, and they can be a bit a pricey.  It's our unfortunate luck that the only two rolls we ordered were so visually boring.  

Service: It wasn't too busy this late in the evening.  A handful of people at the bar and few people at the tables.  The BF had to ask for his soda to be refilled and the waitress never came back with his drink!  When he asked for it, the waitress got him another one.  Then a few minutes later, she came by and took his drink away!  (We were wondering why she did that.)  When she came back with his drink, she said she was refilling it again.  (I guess to make up for his drink disappearing in the first place.)  The BF asked for my own pot of tea since I'm a big tea drinker and to save them the trouble of having to refill my teacup every five seconds.

One waiter came by twice to take away dishes that we weren't done yet.  In the process, he would try to squeeze in between us to reach for the plate, only to realize there was still food on it.  And finally at the end of our meal when the plate was clearly empty, then he asked if he could take it!  We were amused.  And actually, when we are both done sharing a plate, we actually put it to the side to help them out for that reason - so they don't have to reach in between a couple of lovebirds.  Duh!     

Don't forget that you can get a 10% coupon when you visit their website!

(Yep, there's pics of our food eats in the business profile!)
Oscar is a great chef ! One of the best sushi places in Las Vegas ! Fast service and the sushi is amazing

A hidden jewel in LV! We waited for a table to clear for
About 30 minutes. And everything was WORTH it! I'm picky with Japanese food because I'm from Gardena, CA, where the old school Japanese live and where the best Japanese food is served in Los Angeles.  Osaka Bistro is one of the best I've been. Oh, I don't know the owner but he was so Nice! Guys try this place next time you go to Vegas!
Tatami mat area cool. All sashimi fresh. Good service.  Iconic restaurant if you read history.  Benihana type cooking area may have been better choice for comfort.

I brought my boyfriend and our good friends for dinner on Tuesday. We had a great time. Our friends were delighted by the ambiance of the dining area. The sushi was wonderful. We had three bottles of the Zipang Sake and it was priced just right. Cheesecake with strawberries along with two different flavors of Mochi. The mango was really good, but not a big fan of the green tea Mochi. Always be back to this restaurant!

When first pulling up to the parking lot, don't be scared off like we almost were.  The area is filled with adult themed stores (stripper shoes and attire, adult toys...).  The doors are solid, no windows or anything.  The area looked kind of sketchy.  We decided to go in anyway since the general reviews were good.  I had the chirashi and my wife had the tempura udon (ramen?).  Both were excellent for the price.  Total without drinks or sides was just over $20!  We will definitely come back next time we are in town.
Always a sure bet. Had octopus there for the first time this past winter and was impressed.

Lol just walked in there. Kind of laughable how 3 servers and a bartender were have a wonderful conversation at the bar NOT acknowledging customers who walk in. Disappointing. I mean you can stare at us, but like are we going to be seated by you or serve ourselves? Walked out. Never got a chance to eat at the restaurant. Will not be returning.

Exterior was super random and it's in a strip mall but I was pretty surprised to find a cool little spot that's been there since 1967! Attentive service and a huge menu. The large seating area for groups is super super cool.

All I can say about the sushi here is it's amazing. I told my wife to take me somewhere we have never been for sushi together and she chose Osaka because she remembered loving it 6 years ago. Now here for some information on Osaka.

Exterior: I would consider this a hidden gem that is in plain view. I have passed it easily 20-30 times without ever noticing it. It looks like your average chinese restaurant with small signs and red neon lighting all around the place. Don't let this deceive you.

Interior: As soon as you enter the building you feel like your'e in a different world. I'm not saying it's high class but compared to the exterior it looks good. They have three different areas to sit depending on the experience you would like which I enjoyed. You can have your usual sushi experience next to the sushi bar with a couple small tables for couples, a sushi chef prepare your food directly infront of you while he is doing all kind of tricks and making balls of fire, who doesn't like fire? And lastly they take a more traditional approach which I did and liked, you go to a seperate room with enclosed booth style seating where you remove your shoes and sit on small cushions. Cool experience.

Staff: The staff were great. Everyone acted professionally, gave advice on what rolls were ordered most and preferred by other guests, and the service was on point.

Now for the most important part, sushi: The sushi was absolutely amazing!!! We ordered the "Titanic boat" which came with a large variety of sushi on a huge boat. It came with 12 pieces of Nigiri (6 salmon, 3 albacore, and 3 tuna) and they melted in your mouth. The fish was so delicate and well prepared I will definitely be back for more. It also came with 5 other half rolls. I apologize as I can't remember the names of them but can assure you each and every bite was delicious. I have been to numerous sushi restaurants in town, many in California, and have a friend who owns one in south Vegas, and this destroys them all. Sorry for being a traitor if you read this buddy.

I will upload pictures later for all of you to drool at your computers. Enjoy.

Saw this on Triple D's, first sushi place in Vegas, so yeah gotta try this place out. The lighting is dim and it is casual. We sat in a kinda private booth area, no shoes, so you sit crisscross or yes for those that cannot sit that way you can sit as you normally would in a chair there's room for your legs under the table still. 

We came in right when they open since we were heading driving back home after.

Sushi was very fresh and good. We came in time for the lunch special and order every roll on the lunch special which can included a few signature ones. Hey why not, we definitely wanted to try it all. For sure it was worth it and we did finish it! 

If your craving sushi come give this place a try and get the experience of the semi- traditional seating area.
Nice atmosphere. Not too crowded for a Friday night. Opted for the traditional seating. Had a couple of roles and tried a couple sake samplers. Overall a good time and would come again.

This restaurant is a long-standing, family-run restaurant for sushi, teppanyaki and other traditional Japanese foods. 

I got the pork katsu curry and it wasn't bad. The katsu was crispy and the curry sauce was kinda tasty. The complimentary miso soup was bland, but it had noodle and a slice of kamaboko. 

Tatami rooms and teppan room are available. 

We had a birthday at our party and the restaurant gave her a complimentary birthday ice cream. She got two scoops of ice cream (green tea and mango) with whip cream and candle on top.

3 stars!!

Osaka Japanese Bistro is almost yummylicious!!
i like this location the best!!!! waiters are nice and very friendly and we love the tatami room and i don't know why their food is better. I just love the atmosphere and everything about it.

The service here is exceptional! The food is really fresh and the presentation is exceptional. Need towels in the bathroom. Had the sashimi sald and the green tea. Green tea was amazing and bottomless! Would come again. My 13 year loved the ambiance.
Bad service.. nothing special with food.. too upset to mention what kind of service they gave us...  just a waste of time to go here..
Fantastic service, excellent variety of sushi  and sake!!! Restaurant is quite, quaint, and fast service :)
Our waiter made some suggestions and we went ahead and ordered them. not disappointed!  Enjoyed everything and the sushi was fresh as always!

I'd give 1/2 star, but Yelp doesn't allow that. Just finished eating here for lunch...did you know they import bugs from a farm?! We didn't either until there was a bug affixed to my chop stick. Asked for the manager, that was a struggle too...finally got to talk to the owner Gene who informed us the bug must have come from the farm. No sorry, just information of where the bug used to reside. So if you are up for a little excitement in your dining experience, try the salad and ask for extra imported bugs.
Since I don't think I'll make it to JP anytime soon, I like to believe this is just about the same!!! Nice atmosphere, yummy food, & a decent wait staff!!!

Food was good, wait staff was nice, chef's cook with good quality and nice speed. Only thing I hate about this place is how small it is. It's always over crowded and people always squeezing by next to you behind you bumping into each other. If they moved to a bigger locale I'd be there all the time. I'd recommend but won't return to the sardine can.

The BEST spot for teppan in Las Vegas. My husband and I love this place! It's the chef that really makes the experience with teppan and chef phong at this location is fantastic! Such a friendly guy and his food is exceptional. Tonight my husband ordered the lobster and it was some of the best we have ever had. The rolls are quite good as well and they also have the traditional Japanese area with the low tables and floor mats which is very cool. Definitely worth giving it a try, you won't regret it!

I went to an early dinner here with 2 coworkers. We walked in around 4:45 pm. The place was pretty dead and we even for a second thought that they were closed. Guess we were just early! We all ordered the shrimp & chicken off the teppan grill menu. The only seasoning I saw them put on the chicken, shrimp, rice & veggies was just salt, pepper and butter. I felt it needed more flavor. Something to set it apart from regular old chicken & shrimp. I feel like Geisha House gives their teppan meals more flavor than salt & pepper. Overall, portion sizes were good like they always should be. You leave full and satisfied. Our chef was awesome and nice. Our waiter was super nice and even chatted with us for a little. He wasn't awkward or antisocial. We had a good dinner.

My husband and I came here on first trip to Vegas; and we weren't really expecting much because it's a little in coast and were from the coast. But we were wrong. Their sushi is exceptionally good. We got the tons special and it can definitely feed more then 2! We also got a few other things too. The service was really good; our server David was very attentive. They have some food options for desert. I would for sure recommend banana foster cake!

Food was okay.
Grilled salmon was good.
Yakitori portion was small and overcooked, meat was too tough and dry.

One thing we laughed so hard was that there was a menu saying "kintama udon" in Japanese writing. Do you know what that means? "BALLS UDON" yes, the balls!! Men's testicles!! LOL
I've never heard such thing in my life! I wonder if they knew it when they created their menu. Lol
We were laughing so hard that the waiter guy asked us if we are okay lol then we explained about the kintama udon thing and he said "oh yeah, every Japanese customer laughs" oh man I died that day.

Yes! Yes! Yes!!!!

I was fortunate enough to be introduced to Osaka's for my future brother in law's birthday. I like sushi, so I was anticipating your usual run of the mill sushi, not expecting anything super fantastic.

Boy was I wrong!

I can't say enough great things about Osaka. The food is excellent! It tastes fresh always, and the variety of rolls is outstanding! There is something for every palate! Even my fianc who was not so keen on sushi, at least once a week asks me, "so when do you want to go back to Osaka's?" 

The atmosphere is great! The minute you walk through the door you get greeted by everyone (or so it seems) you can sit in tables close to the bar, but I believe to get the full experience you need to sit in the Japanese room. Remember to take off your shoes!

All in all, if you want a sushi place with great friendly service, great atmosphere, and all with great prices, come to Osaka! I promise you won't be disappointed!

Amazing selection of specialty rolls and appetizers. Unfortunately they don't have AYCE... BUT the rolls are so good, it's worth it. They have a ton of unique and tasty sauces and make everything they serve taste like a little piece of heaven. Favorites include: The Virgin Roll (a great starter sushi roll for those just venturing into sushi town), Japanese Lasagna, Lisa Lisa, U-My Roll (which is a mouth full, for sure). 

They have a bunch of different seating options (Dining Room, Japanese style tables, and Teppan) and it's a really cute place. Overall, one of my favorites and it's not far from the strip (at least it doesn't seem that far, but nothing does when it tastes good!!).

This place gets points for ambiance, they have intimate rooms with tatami mats where you mimic the Japanese custom of eating while sitting on the ground. The service was speedy and attentive as well. After ten p.m. Until closing at 2:00 they offer discounted dishes, and this is the menu we ordered off of. The seafood salad was fresh, but it had crab in it and I prefer Tuna or salmon this is just a personal preference thing. The rolls were all very fresh. They're shrimp tempura was excellent. This place is great for a date.

We've been coming here for many years-in the 15 years we lived in Las Vegas and 9 years since we've left but returned to visit family. This review is a compilation of all our visits. Osaka is one of our favorite places especially as far as ambiance in LV. 

We tend to go to dinner early so there are fewer people and we have the back to ourselves. The sushi bar and bar area gets pretty noisy during happy hour as does the teppanyaki room. So, going early has lots of benefits. We enjoy sitting at the sushi bar on occasion but my favorite is the quiet tatami rooms in the back. The tatami rooms are low tables and seats where you remove your shoes before heading down into a cozy space. 

We are such creatures of habit when we do sushi. We always get a hot saki, a Kirin beer, miso soup and shrimp & veggie tempura. Then we change it up-though hubs often has a Chiarashi bowl so he gets lots of different things. They have updated the menu since we started and have a good variety of selections. Osaka does a really good Chiarashi. In fact, I think everything we've had is good. 

The past few times we've been there has been with friends for a special occasion and they prefer the teppanyaki tables. We wouldn't go to the teppanyaki table on our own but it's it's nice to do the tables for a special occasion. We usually reserve the whole table and have even had to add a couple seats to fit everyone. They entertain the group though it makes chatting a bit more difficult except to the ones closest to you. We have had steak or shrimp which they cook nicely-despite all the activities on the cook top. The meat come with rice and veggies.

We do recommend Osaka. It is a wonderful place with a variety of areas in one restaurant to have a nice quiet dinner, a fun happy hour or special occasions.

Great place for sushi! Amazing menu. 
Call for a reservation if u want a private table tho.
Worst sushi ever. For the owner - Please step up and do better. It's shame to serve such a good traditional food in  very poorly way.

I don't usually write reviews for restaurants unless I am super compelled to. Which I am. Osaka Japanese Bistro is absolutely amazing! I ordered a salmon nigiri sushi and Tonkotsu. The cuts were delicious and high quality. The Tonkotsu still haunts my mouth. I was in Osaka, Japan last year and the authenticity of this place is very, very spot on. I highly recommend checking this place out.

Location feels dated, and it's in a converted night club club or something, it has no windows, feels like a shady basement somewhere. A lot of the detailing is left over from the 1980s. Sushi bar is cramped and boring, only noise is from the tv showing some random show. Though their servers are friendly and helpful, the chefs are not. I dislike the feel of this place immensely. 
Sushi and cooking is very average for above average prices. It's fresh enough, but flavors don't pop, nothing stood out, and a lot of their recipes are dated. And the half rolls on their happy hour menu really don't save you much. 
They have Tatami rooms and a small teppanyaki grill area that feels like a fire hazard. Area of town is sketchy, parking lot feels unsafe after dark.
Not going back.
A good place to get away from the Vegas strip. Sushi is decent and not as over priced as other places.

I randomly stumbled upon this little gem on my way to the camera shop down the street. I came for lunch on a Thursday and there were 5 other patrons there, who seemed to be regulars. This is a non-tourist, low-key casual spot; my kind of place when I'm bumming it during the week. 
The decor is a bit dated, but that's irrelevant because the food and service make up for it in every way. 
Our waitress, Misu, was sweet and attentive and the sushi was ultra fresh. 
I'll definitely be back soon.

I'll start by saying that I am SUPER picky about sushi. 

This place has a really cool ambiance, with traditional-style seating in the back which we loved. They had some great specials and a very extensive menu. 

I got the california crunch rolls, dragon rolls, and seaweed salad, which is my go-to at any sushi place. The rolls were huge and so fresh and tasty. 

As a group we shared mochi and the tempura bananas for dessert - all the desserts are HUGE (don't let the pictures fool you) and delicious. 

Highly recommend!

Very good quality and great prices! Best of all you can get delivery from them :) I'm always skeptical getting sushi delivery because it's not a food that sits well for long. Tried the delivery though and it was so fresh! Definitely recommend this place if you want quality but don't want to break the bank.

Now that Yelp is offering delivery from so many excellent restaurants, there really should be an option to mark the review "in-house, "take out," or "delivery." 

I've eaten at Osaka once before, in-house, for a birthday treat. It was before Yelp, but I would have posted a very favorable review for it back then. My only criticism would have been that they didn't serve pickles with the rice.

This review is for their delivery service through Yelp.

I recently reviewed another sushi establishment based on a delivery order. I was disappointed then; this experience was so much better!

The sushi we ordered was prepared beautiful, generous but not overly big slivers of fresh, sweet fish on expertly prepared rice. And the presentation, for delivery food, was excellent. They even included that plastic "grass," which is annoying, but at least is says "we tried!" All the boxes were labeled with the menu item they included, a really nice touch! And the order was correct; a blessing. We asked for extra chopsticks and wasabi, and they sent us service for eight, with enough wasabi and ginger to keep our nasal passages clean for a month!

We ordered tempura as well, and that's where this establishment lost its fifth star. The tempura was a bit heavy and oily. The dense oily texture was due in part, I'm sure, to "delivery time lapse," because tempura is meant to be eaten hot out of the oil. Even a few minutes left sitting will cause it become oily. And reheating is problematic, as the shrimp will be over cooked and the veggies limp. So even though it's really no one's fault but mine (for ordering it), I still had to pull that last star. 

This place is not cheap. You can balance the price with the quality though, and order judiciously. And certainly, a couple of rolls and a side would be a better value, but I prefer traditionally prepared nigiri, so we ordered no rolls.

We'll be returning to the restaurant later this month for my birthday; a Living Social deal so very budget friendly. And I can heartily recommend this restaurant for its delivery service! Well, except the tempura, but if you order fried food for delivery, it's your fault!

I give this place 3.5 stars. The only time I have really come here is late night during happy hour. Not sure if I would come in during non-happy hour. I usually order sushi rolls, and maybe their sake sampler or just water. I like their Tatami rooms but the place is older and activity in the surrounding area can feel sketchy. I double check my car and make sure I don't have any items of valuable visible from the outside to tempt some passerby from possibly breaking in. The restaurant itself is borderline dive status but the staff is nice and friendly. Although I did seem to almost get into a debate with one of the servers, one time, over the correct pronunciation of lychee. Whenever I would say, "lie-chee" he would respond back saying, "lee-chee". I'm sure he pronounces tomatoe as "toe-mah-toe," but I digress.

Never had an issue with the place being super busy. They have a Teppanyaki grill area but I have never tried it so I cannot give an opinion. The food is decent and their prices are more or so on par with many of the other sushi places here in town. Maybe a couple items priced higher than other places I have been to. I am a repeat customer and will stop by again if it's during happy hour and I happen to be in the area.

I was recommended to try the sushi here by a friend of mine and was pretty good. I ordered a white tiger roll, banzai roll, and a oh kamisama. They gave the option of either a full roll or half. I ordered half rolls. The price was right and the service was great. This place does not offer all you can eat. I also tried the OG special which was similar to crispy spicy tuna appetizer. The only negative thing is the parking. It's real small and if the place gets busy you may have to park in the parking lot next to business. There is a server there named Jared that helped us and he was great. Very attentive and nice. Anyone that goes there be sure to ask for him. You won't be disappointed. Everything I ordered was recommended by him and was delicious.
Best spicy adamame in town! The service and food are always consistent. I come here weekly and I don't get tired of it,happy hour is my favorite. Definetly one of my favorite sushi places.

Very unique place. A bit intimidating from the outside as there are no windows, just a door. The menu is vast. Ramen was not worth the calories but the fried rice and spicy tuna were excellent. I'd say stick with the sushi if you come here. Service was great.

I've heard so many great things about Osaka Japanese Bistro so of course the hubby and I had to try it when we were in Las Vegas last week.  Both him and I love sushi so we had high expectations going in here.

We chose to dine in one of their tatami rooms since we really wanted to experience the authentic Japanese style of dining.  The tatami rooms do provide somewhat a feeling of intimacy and privacy so it was a nice change.

We ordered their sashimi platter (ahi tuna, yellow tail tuna, salmon, albacore), kim chee, miso soup (perfect blend of sweet and salty), a kamikaze roll (eel roll with sweet sauce), spider roll (deep fried soft shell crab roll with sprouts), white tiger (tuna roll flame cooked on top with a white sauce), tuna-poki (our favorite of all dishes, the slices were super thin and fresh, tossed in a light sesame oil dressing with sweet thin slices of seaweed), and a Nigori sake sampler (apple, strawberry, and lychee flavor - our favorite).  

We were pleasantly surprised that everything tasted so fresh and all the dishes came out fast.  Prices were not too bad considering we were in Las Vegas.  We spent a total of $130 total for all our dishes including drinks and tip so not bad for a really good sushi joint.  Would definitely love to come back here when we're in town again.

I'm rating 2 stars because the food arrived very quickly. I have been eating at this restaurant since my cousins family opened. Although the food arrived quickly it was cold and the portions were very small. It was average teriyaki at best.  Very tough slice of beef and very dry. Gyoza was over cooked.

Vast menu and really well executed Japanese fairs.

Casual yet elegantly presented decor.

You will enjoy coming back to try new dishes/styles

We unfortunately got a chef on his first night and we were his first table. He came to the table and seemed quite unsure of himself when he lit the grill the flames were very high and he let it stay lit until it burned away. He was only able to start to cook one thing at once, until he was finishing cooking my lobster. He then added raw chicken to the grill and used the same spatula and knife and than tossed my lobster with it. This was a cross contamination and it was disgusting to watch. We ordered fried rice and he left egg shells in it. He did no special tricks except trying to set the onion on fire, but he even messed that up. He kept dropping the towels and than picking them up to wipe of his spatula and knife. The worst part was when he put the steaks on the grill.  One was bright red and looked fresh the other one was brown. We pointed out the steak being brown he said it was only cut an hour ago. He offered to put teriyaki sauce on it to cover up the mistake. When he put it on my plate it had a bad smell. I refused to eat it. We explained to the waiter who was nice that we were not happy. They still made us pay for all the meals, but took of a small amount for the steak. This was a terrible experience and unfortunately my Mother's birthday and now her memory of her special day is tainted.
I always pass this place and very committed to my sushi bars. BUT this place blew me away and this place is amazing I am definitely coming back thank you Osaka !!!

My favorite sushi place in town. Love all their rolls, they fish are really fresh and the chefs there are very creative. Everything I even try there are very yummy. The services are alway friendly. And they open late at night. This is one of those hidden neighborhood jem.

ALSO, lots of bad reviews regarding Osake are for the other one by Lake Mead, most people mistake the two. I been to that one too and they are one of the worst. It's night and day. Please don't let that mislead you.

Recent visit tells me this place is still consistently very good. We've had the sushi, donburi, udon and combo teriyaki dishes and all were high quality. The decor could use an update but the food is reliably excellent!
Best sushi in town! Always fresh and great customer service:) Asakusa roll is my fave!

I come out to this place at least twice a month, usually during happy hour from 10 pm to 2 am.  The location is suspect but this is the very first sushi place in LV so there you go.

The late night menu is awesome.  Ultimate osaka roll, japanese lasagna and kai's special are my favorites.  You can get stuffed with the happy hour appetizers too.  Try the chicken wings, the kalbi sticks and the fried rice.  Oh and the udon too.  I am not sure why some prior reviews say this place is expensive.  In my opinion, this place is very reasonable and I have not been disappointed. 

P.S. Green tea tiramisu is really good.  A little expensive at $8 for a slice but splurge once in a while.
Great Las Vegas staple....sushi is great fresh and prepared wonderfully. What a great place to enjoy Japanese in Vegas

Quality, mouth melting, fresh sushi and sashimi. Most of the nigiri and roll sushi pricing was spot on (reasonable esp for Vegas) but the pricing on few of the items left me scratching my head wondering if they came sprinkled with gold flakes on top. Overall good place to go for sushi. Service was satisfactory; No complaints nor compliments (We did have a fairly large group though). Seating is either sushi bar, table, or tatami. They also have a few teppan grill tables.

I was immediately surprised by the way we had to take off our shoes and sit at the table on pillows- it made the experience a lot more authentic. The portions were a bit smaller than I would like, probably because I was so used to the sushi buffets in the east coast. Great quality food, although the mochi ice creams were tiny. Would reccomend if you're in vegas and do not want to eat on the crowded strip.
My favorite sushi place in all of Vegas.  Fast turn over and fresh fish. Great late night specials and excellent service.  A must try!

I have been going to Osaka since 2005!  It's AMAZING!!!!  I mean, quality fish...friendly service.  The 777 is my FAVORITE!!!!!  When we lived overseas for a few years we'd come back once a year.  I'd make sure to head straight to Osaka for my 777 and much more!!  Whew...really amazing place...you have to try it!
Always come here for the night special. Salmon kama, black sausage, fried rice, spicy tuna, Kalbi sticks, Lisa Lisa role, kamikaze, lasagna roll n top off with tempura ice cream.

This place rules, I visit it every time I visit vegas. It is a hole in the wall, sketchy strip mall location and feels like it used to be a bar or something with the weird hallway entrance. They are open late and have an awesome late night happy hour. The staff is excellent and the food is great. They will make sushi off menu and will do a very thinly sliced japanese tuna that no other place has been able to get right for me. I have tried other menu items and everything has been great, good portion size and value to go along with the great service and quality.
Decent japanese in vegas area. Usually,people go to japanese all you can eat but quality isnt good. Osaka had very good quality of fish.

I came here when evening with my family and we did to her Baci Grill my son had such a nice time I had the lobster and the scallops everything was traditional everything was fine we sat with some good people it's a little bit hard to find unless you have your navigator on because you will drive right past it I've done it twice
Don't forget that if you come at an odd time you might have to wait for seating so that they have a Knouff to start their presentation but they do the traditional volcano and anything that you would get any hibachi restaurant

It's been around for years so I don't know why anyone would give it a bad review
Desserts are excellent. Fried oreo was yummy. Sorry to inform everyone but happy hour equals half a roll! Just not what I am used to when I go for happy hour.

Anything less than 4 stars is blasphemy.

If this place were in San Diego they would give Ota-san a run for his money!!

Great lunch menu. Service, good.  Food, delicious.   The reason it doesn't get 5 stars is the restaurant itself.  Very dingy, needs updating, restrooms smelled bad, carpets looked gross.   Just close your eyes and open your mouth and you'll be alright!

We went in for a late lunch, kind of in a hurry. We picked 3 lunch special rolls, the 911, the white tiger, and Kai's special. We also ordered a full Tropical roll. The service was prompt and it was the best sushi we've had in a long time.
What a great place for a tapanyaki nights! The food is amazing. I couldn't stop complimenting through out the entire dinner course!
